ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: Speciation Compatibility Threshold Equation
ygData.msgSnippet: Hope everybody had a happy Thanksgiving. :) ... I m not sure what you mean by this.  Basically, I think we re going to normalize for chromosome size, and set

Date: Sun, 30 Nov 2003 10:06:45 -0800 (PST)
Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Speciation Compatibility Threshold Equation
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
In-Reply-To: <bq5uor+muv8@...>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-eGroups-Remote-IP: 216.109.116.127
From: Derek James <blue5432@...>
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=34004016
X-Yahoo-Profile: blue5432

Hope everybody had a happy Thanksgiving. :)

> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James
> <blue5432@y...> wrote:
> > I think the basic approach Philip and I are going
> to
> > take is to calculate some sort of percentage
> > difference between chromosomes for usage as a
> > speciation threshold.  If we find that our
> populations
> > are either underspeciation or overspeciating, then
> > we'll modify the threshold to be dynamic.
> > 
--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> When will you calculate this difference?  During
> evolution
> itself?  Or some kind of preprocessing?  

I'm not sure what you mean by this.  Basically, I
think we're going to normalize for chromosome size,
and set the compatibility threshold to something like
0.1.  We'll do a number of runs in a couple of
different domains, keeping an eye on the number of
species that form throughout the run.  If the
population is either underspeciating or
overspeciating, we'll probably employ some sort of
dynamic threshold that modifies its value based on the
number of species in the population.

> Yes true I agree.  But there is a number under which
> I think realtive size is less important.  I just
> don't
> know what that number is.

Yes, you're probably right that there is a number
under which relative size isn't that important.  20
was your cutoff point in your original NEAT paper,
which sounds reasonable to me.

You said that in your robot duel experiments, genomes
grew to 200-300 genes, and you still had N set to 1. 
But you also said that you were using a dynamic
speciation threshold, right?  So the compatibility
threshold fluctuated, probably between 3.0 and some
larger values.  This essentially has the same
practical effect of normalizing for chromosome size,
doesn't it?  It's a way of comparing the difference in
two individuals relative to the size of the
chromosomes (as well as keeping the number of species
stable).  

> But the NN's we are evolving
> right now are 
> far from being capable of "deciding" on their own
> whom to mate with,
> so something has to make the decision for them.

I wasn't really talking about sexual selection.  What
I was getting at is that often in nature, two
individuals are genetically compatible, but
phenotypically incompatible.

For example, until most organisms reach some sort of
developmental maturity, they are incapable of
reproducing (this goes not only for
sexually-reproducing organisms, but many
asexually-reproducing ones).

Two infants of a given species may be incapable of
physically reproducing, even though they are
genetically compatible.

Many organisms do not end up reproducing because of
developmental problems.  Their genotype hasn't
properly encoded for an organism that is able to
develop to the point of reproductive viability.

Should an indirectly-encoded GA that includes some
sort of developmental stage for phenotypes not also
have similar standards for reproduction?  That is, if
a genotype cannot encode for an individual that
develops into a mature, functioning phenotype, should
it be allowed to reproduce?

> You cannot mate two phenotypes unless you have a
> direct encoding. 
> When people mate, it's their DNA that's recombining
> not their bodies.
> I'm not sure where environmental influence comes
> into play.
> If the DNA are not compatible, they won't produce an
> offspring
> regardless of the environment.  I suppose if their
> DNA is compatible
> there could still be some kind of physical injury or
> pathology in
> one of the organisms preventing mating, but this
> hardly seems
> important for artificial evolution.  So I don't
> think the environment
> is relevant here.  

Well, that's what I was getting at above.  It's not
just pathology or injury that keeps phenotypes from
mating, but also their stage of development.  And the
development is dependent upon the environment.

Is this important in artificial evolution?  I don't
know.  But it's extremely important in natural
evolution (e.g., a significant percentage of
phenotypes never make it beyond the very first
developmental stages).  Many genotypes are selected
against based on their inability to construct viable
phenotypes.

So far, our evolutionary models are not very rich. 
There aren't many EAs that employ the sort of
artificial embryogeny that you wrote about.  But as
the models do become more complex, maybe some of these
concepts from natural evolution (such as embryonic
viability) will become more important.

> I agree that how something develops contributes to
> its fitness
> and the extent to which it should reproduce.  But
> the genome is what
> determines how it should develop!  

That, and its environment, right?  You're not saying
that the genome is the *only* thing that determines
development, are you?

> All humans (more or less) are
> compatible for
> mating, whether the least intelligent and most
> physically unfit, or
> the geniuses with olympic potential.  They are all
> the same species.
> DNA doesn't care who's more fit when the mating
> happens.

Well, humans that are of a particular sexual
development.  Humans that have not reached puberty are
incapable of mating, as are women who reach menopause,
and of course all those phenotypes that are sterile or
impotent for one reason or another.

In principle, you're right.  But part of the beauty of
the way NEAT handles compatibility is also a problem. 
Basically, *any* two individuals are inherently
capable of reproducing in NEAT.  We're forcing
somewhat arbitrary decisions about which reproductive
groups to fence off, based on differences in their
genotypes.

In NEAT, from a reproductive standpoint, all genotypes
are theoretically compatible.  It is only the
speciation compatibility threshold that determines who
gets to mate with whom.  In nature, it's not an
analysis of genetic compatibility that decides whether
or not a butterfly can mate with a goat.  

> Here's the important point:  Can you imagine a
> single amino acid
> mutation in a human that actually creates a new
> species!? 

What you're basically saying (if I'm hearing you
right) is that nature favors mutations that
individually do not have a significant impact on the
development of the phenotype, as opposed to the
"hopeful monster" hypothesis (that drastic mutations
can sometimes provide larger jumps in evolution).  As
far as I know, this issue is still debated among
evolutionary biologists.

The late Stephen J. Gould was a proponent of the idea
that macromutations led to drastic changes in
morphology by affecting the genes that controlled
embryonic development.  I'm not saying I agree with
Gould.  I'm just saying that the issue isn't
necessarily a clear-cut one.  

If I'm hearing you right, though, the idea of
canalization is that mutations never have a drastic
impact on the phenotype, no matter whether the gene
they affect encodes for a single trait or is copied
millions of times over to produce the resulting
phenotype.  In the case of neuroevolution, this would
seem to argue for very low mutation rates, wouldn't
it?  Especially with indirect encoding schemes.
 
> In contrast, if you look at an indirect encoding
> like L-systems
> for example, changing a single character in the
> string can
> have massive impact, creating *unrecognizable*
> offspring.  I think
> that's a pretty good sign that L-systems are not
> canalized like
> DNA, and that we have to develop better encodings.

I haven't ever taken a embryology class, though I'm
interested to know the average rate of fatal
mutations.  I know that there is a significant rate of
miscarriages among humans (many are not even noticed),
and I wonder to what extent this is caused by
mutations that adversely affect development. 
Basically, I'm interested to know just how robust DNA
is.

> I mentioned 3 things in that paper that can lead to
> canalization:
> Stochasticity, Resource Allocation, and
> Overproduction.

I'll definitely revisit your paper and have a look.
  
> Also canalization means different parts of the
> system can
> pick up slack when other parts are altered.  So even
> if the
> blood cell type alters slightly, the parts the blood
> cells interact
> with may themselves be flexible in those
> interactions, such that
> they can deal with a slightly altered counterpart.

Okay, well that makes sense.  It seems to me that with
neuroevolution, we're dealing with an inherently
robust phenotype, wouldn't you say?  That is, if we
were using NEAT to produce evolvable hardware (say, a
walking machine), that sort of phenotype may be more
brittle, in terms of the effects of new mutations on
an individual's fitness.

> To me it's
> inconceivable; it is clear
> that evolution requires the accumulation of many
> many mutations over
> many generations to get an entirely new character.

Well, I'd never argue that a single mutation leads to
a new species in natural biology.  Natural speciation
is much more complex than that.  It's also much more
complex than the model for speciation we're using
currently with NEAT.  In NEAT, a single mutation *can*
lead to a new species.

In natural ecosystems, it is sometimes geographical
constraints that lead to the reproductive isolation of
a given subpopulation that then leads to the emergence
of a new species.  Obviously, our model doesn't
account for this sort of spatio-temporal aspect
either.  

> It's not exactly "where you draw the line" that 
> matters, but that
> you do draw it somewhere and with some regularity.

Well, I think it is an interesting question of how
"where you draw the line" affects evolution.

> Here my big concern:  If you really propose to
> compare
> phenotypes for speciation, you are back to the
> competing
> conventions problem with different topologies 
> that NEAT solves.  We are literally back at square
> one.
> Can you imagine the kind of graph theory analysis
> necessary
> to establish that two morphologies are the same
> species?
> It isn't even about macro-level similarity.  A human
> with
> no arms or legs is still human.  

But a human with no reproductive organs cannot
reproduce, even though it may be
genetically-compatible with other humans.

I'm not proposing reproductive organs for our neural
nets, though this is very much how nature determines
whether or not individuals can reproduce (and with
whom).  Very far down the line, the way artificial
organisms are divided into reproductive populations
may be based on the way natural species are divided,
and not by an algorithm that determines genetic
compatibility.  But I'd concede that it is a much more
efficient, much more likely paradigm for the near
future.

Just curious...I'm guessing that most people here in
the group come from a computer science background.  Is
that an incorrect assumption?  Neuroevolution is a
multi-disciplinary field, so are there any people here
with more experience in say, biology, psychology, or
neuroscience than in computer science?

Derek
